metadata.case_name: Indian Cable Company Ltd. v. Their Workmen

facts.text: Appellant is a Public Limited Company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, 1913, manufactures and sells electric cables, wires etc., registered office at Calcutta, factory at Jamshedpur.
Before January 1, 1956, appellant sold goods through agents Messrs Gillanders Arbuthnot and Co.

B.I.C.C. Ltd. (British Insulated Callenders Cables Ltd.) carried on business in India with branches at Bombay, Madras, Calcutta, Delhi, Trivandrum, Ahmedabad, Nagpur, Kanpur, Bangalore and Ambala; decided to stop trading and close branches end of 1955.
Appellant took over B.I.C.C. Ltd. branches from January 1, 1956; offered reemployment to most workmen on terms in communication dated November 23, 1955, which they accepted.
Ambala branch business included sale of appellant's goods and execution of B.I.C.C. Ltd. contracts with Government of Punjab taken over by appellant.
Beginning of 1958, contracts nearing completion; appellant considered Ambala branch unremunerative due to volume of own business, decided to close it.
On May 8, 1958, appellant terminated services of all 11 workmen at Ambala branch, paid salaries, wages in lieu of notice, retrenchment compensation, gratuity, provident fund; wound up branch.
Workmen accepted amounts; appellant says without protest and cooperated; workmen say under protest (nothing turns on this).

On June 5, 1958, six workmen sent representation to management: closure unjustified, retrenchment per All India seniority as branches one unit, right to employment in other branches. Copy to Punjab Government.

Punjab Government notification February 2, 1959, referred dispute to Industrial Tribunal, Punjab under s.10 of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947: Whether retrenchment of six workmen justified/legal under s.25G; whether seniority pooled across branches; if not, relief.
Tribunal overruled appellant's preliminary objections on August 17, 1959.
Tribunal award February 11, 1960: direct appellant to take back six workmen from May 8, 1958, no break in continuity, pay full wages till absorbed.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

Shri A.N. Gujral appointed Tribunal April 28, 1953; reappointed presiding officer April 9, 1957; Punjab Act 8 of 1957 raised retirement age; term expired June 4, 1959; Shri Passey appointed successor; award by Passey.
November 23, 1955 communication: workmen stationed in same place, similar work as with B.I.C.C.
Branches prepare own accounts, forwarded for consolidation; different scales of pay per branch; no routine transfers without consent.
Each branch has own Labour Union.
No union of Ambala branch moved; Delhi union wrote to Conciliation Officer Dec 10, 1958, withdrawn; Commercial Employees Union Delhi not established; post-reference unions supported.
Tribunal finding: no strict proof of common pool of seniority; branches separate entities but component parts of Calcutta unit; company as industrial unit.

legal_issues.text: Competence of the Tribunal to entertain/adjudicate the reference.
Competence of Punjab Government to make the reference dated February 2, 1959.
Whether disputes were industrial disputes or individual disputes under s.2(k).
Whether Ambala branch was an industrial establishment within s.25G; whether retrenchment justified/legal under s.25G; whether seniority pooled across all branches.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal not competent; Shri A.N. Gujral's appointments invalid; Punjab Act 8 of 1957 repugnant to Art.14; no valid pendency before successor Shri Passey.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes Act ss.7A, 7B, 7C; Art.14 Constitution

petitioner_arguments.text: Punjab Government not competent to refer after closure of Ambala branch on May 8, 1958; no place of business in Punjab.
Disputes individual, not industrial disputes; requires support by union or considerable number of workmen.
Ambala branch separate industrial establishment; closed bona fide; no retrenchment as no continuing industry; s.25G inapplicable.

respondent_arguments.text: Closure unjustified; all branches one unit; retrenchment per All India seniority basis.
s.2(k) includes dispute with single workman per interpretation rules.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes Act s.2(k); General Clauses Act s.13; R v. National Arbitration Tribunal

respondent_arguments.text: Six workmen joined; majority in Ambala (6/11); unions supported.
Common control, employment, balance sheet, service conditions show one establishment.

court_reasoning.text: Overruled preliminary objection on Tribunal competence following Atlas Cycle Industries Ltd. v. Their Workmen and Dalmia Dadri Cement Ltd. v. Shri A.N. Gujral.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appointments valid; Punjab Act not unconstitutional.

court_reasoning.text: Did not decide Punjab Govt jurisdiction as not necessary given view on s.25G.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cause of action analysis if closure disputed, but proceeded to s.25G.

court_reasoning.text: Dispute industrial if affects workmen as class; requires union or considerable section support preceding reference; here no such prior support; but decided on branch as separate establishment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Six out of 11 majority if branch separate.

court_reasoning.text: Industrial establishment local; branches distinct per location, no functional integrality (different pay scales, no routine transfers); Ambala separate; closure valid, no s.25G violation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tests: geographical proximity, unity of management/control, functional integrality, etc.; decisive: location and one code for categories/wages.

holdings.text: Ambala branch separate industrial establishment under s.25G.
Dispute industrial as raised by majority of Ambala branch workmen.
No relief under s.25G as establishment closed bona fide.

statutes_cited.relevance: Reference power; industrial dispute definition; retrenchment procedure; tribunal constitution; appropriate govt; industrial establishment

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Tribunal award set aside; reference answered against respondents; no relief to workmen as Ambala branch separate establishment closed bona fide, s.25G inapplicable.

key_quotes.text: "Notwithstanding that the language of s.2(k) is wide enough to cover a dispute between an employer and a single employee, the scheme of the Industrial Disputes Act does appear to contemplate that the machinery provided therein should be set in motion, to settle only disputes which involve the rights of workmen as a class".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines when individual dispute becomes industrial

key_quotes.text: "If in their true relation they constitute one integrated whole we say that the establishment is one if on the contrary they do not constitute one integrated whole, each unit is then a separate unit."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for single vs multiple establishments from Associated Cement

key_quotes.text: "the decisive elements... are the location of the establishment and the functional integrality i.e. the existence of one code relating to the categories of workmen and their scales of wages."
key_quotes.speaker: court
